member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase
member.summary: This base class tries to correctly implement disposable, and should help make the behaviors more consistent across classes that inherit from this class.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.IDisposeLock
member.summary: Unlike forms that have a disposable life cycle with a clear chain of ownership, or purely managed libraries that have in a built in reference counting system, disposable members in DotSpatial require the ability to behave in some cases like a layer that should be removed from memory as soon as it is removed from the map, and other times like a persistent object. The DisposeLock concept works like an industrial lock-out system. Each additional lock increases the lock count. When all users have released the lock, the IsDisposedLocked property will be false, and the next action like a removal from the parent layers will properly dispose the item. Users may feel free to add the lock in order to handle disposal on the layers themselves. These methods will not actually prevent Dispose from functioning, but understand that calling dispose when there is an IsDisposeLocked is true means that there will likely be a problem.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IDisposeLock.LockDispose
member.summary: Locks dispose. This typically adds one instance of an internal reference counter.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IDisposeLock.UnlockDispose
member.summary: Unlocks dispose. This typically removes one instance of an internal reference counter.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IDisposeLock.IsDisposeLocked
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether an existing reference is requesting that the object is not disposed of.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.LockDispose
member.summary: Adds one request or "reference count" for this item not to be disposed. When an owner is finished, if this is 0, then dispose should be called. For now this does not prevent Dispose from being called, it is simply for tracking purposes.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.UnlockDispose
member.summary: Removes one reference or request to prevent an object from being automatically disposed.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.Finalize
member.summary: Finalizes an instance of the class.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: This is where the meat of the dispose work is done. Subclasses should call dispose on any disposable members or internal members (presuming they are not dispose locked).
member.param: True if the "Dispose" method was called instead of the destructor.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this instance has already had the Dispose method called on it.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DisposeBase.IsDisposeLocked
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether there are outstanding references that may be using the item that would prefer it if you did not dispose of the item while they are still using it.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.ExtentMZ
member.summary: For shapefiles, the extents may or may not have M and Z values depending on the file type. These are valid IExtent implementations, but add both the M and Z extent options. For the file format, the Z values are mandatory, and so whatever the values are will be stored. This may cause issues when viewing in ArcGIS if you have entered some bad Z envelope extents.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.ExtentParseException.EXTENT_TEXT_TEMPLATE
member.summary: The string template that should be used. M and Z are optional. Do use a comma to delimit terms, but the space doesn't matter. Do use square brackets to enclose numbers, and do use the | separator to separate min from max. Do place min before max in each term. The order of the terms doesn't matter. Use periods for decimals and an invariant culture.

member.summary: Gets or sets the implementation of IDataManager for the project to use when accessing data. This is THE place where the DataManager can be replaced by a different data manager. If you add this data manager to your project, this will automatically set itself as the DefaultDataManager. However, since each DM will do this, you may have to control this manually if you add more than one DataManager to the project in order to set the one that will be chosen.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter
member.summary: This handles the methodology of progress messaging in one place to make it easier to update.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new progress meter, but doesn't support the IProgressHandler unless one is specified.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.#ctor(DotSpatial.Data.IProgressHandler)
member.summary: A progress meter can't actually do anything without a progressHandler, which actually displays the status.
member.param: An IProgressHandler that will actually handle the status messages sent by this meter.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.#ctor(DotSpatial.Data.IProgressHandler,System.String)
member.summary: A progress meter that simply keeps track of progress and is capable of sending progress messages. This assumes a MaxValue of 100 unless it is changed later.
member.param: Any valid IProgressHandler that will display progress messages
A base message to use as the basic status for this progress handler.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.#ctor(DotSpatial.Data.IProgressHandler,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: A progress meter that simply keeps track of progress and is capable of sending progress messages.
member.param: Any valid implementation if IProgressHandler that will handle the progress function
The message without any progress information.
Percent should show a range between the MinValue and MaxValue. MinValue is assumed to be 0.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.Reset
member.summary: Resets the progress meter to the 0 value. This sets the status message to "Ready.".

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.Next
member.summary: This always increments the CurrentValue by one.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.SendProgress
member.summary: Sends a progress message to the IProgressHandler interface with the current message and progress

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.BaseMessage
member.summary: Gets or sets the string message (without the progress element).

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.Key
member.summary: Gets or sets the string that does not include any mention of progress percentage, but specifies what is occurring.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.CurrentPercent
member.summary: Gets or sets the current integer progress level from 0 to 100. If a new update is less than or equal to the previous value, then no progress will be displayed by the ProgressMeter. Values less than 0 are set to 0. Values greater than 100 are set to 100.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.CurrentValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the current value relative to the specified MaxValue in order to update the progress. Setting this will also update OldProgress if there is an integer change in the percentage, and send a progress message to the IProgressHandler interface.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.EndValue
member.summary: The value that defines when the meter should show as 100% complete. EndValue can be less than StartValue, but values closer to EndValue will show as being closer to 100%.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.Silent
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the progress meter should send messages to the IProgressHandler. By default Silent is false, but setting this to true will disable the messaging portion.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.StartValue
member.summary: The minimum value defines when the meter should show as 0% complete.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.StepPercent
member.summary: An integer value that is 1 by default. Ordinarily this will send a progress message only when the integer progress has changed by 1 percentage point. For example, if StepPercent were set to 5, then a progress update would only be sent out at 5%, 10% and so on. This helps reduce overhead in cases where showing status messages is actually the majority of the processing time for the function.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.PreviousPercent
member.summary: Gets or sets the previous integer progress level from 0 to 100. If a new update is less than or equal to the previous value, then no progress will be displayed by the ProgressMeter. Values less than 0 are set to 0. Values greater than 100 are set to 100.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.ProgressMeter.ProgressHandler
member.summary: Gets or sets the progress handler for this meter

member.summary: Gets or sets the cached extent variable. The public Extent is the virtual accessor, and should not be used from a constructor. MyExtent is protected, not virtual, and is only visible to inheriting classes, and can be safely set in the constructor.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DataSet.ProgressMeter
member.summary: This is an internal place holder to make it easier to pass around a single progress meter between methods. This will use lazy instantiation if it is requested before one has been created.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DataSet.ProjectionString
member.summary: Gets or sets the raw projection string for this dataset. This handles both the case where projection is unavailable but a projection string needs to be passed around, and the case when a string is not recognized by the DotSpatial.Projections library. This is not format restricted, but should match the original data source as closely as possible. Setting this will also set the Projection if the Projection library is available and the format successfully defines a transform by either treating it as an Esri string or a proj4 string.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DataSet.CanReproject
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the DotSpatial.Projections assembly is loaded
member.returns: Boolean, true if the value can reproject.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DataSet.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the string name

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DataSet.Extent
member.summary: Gets or sets the extent for the dataset. Usages to Envelope were replaced as they required an explicit using to DotSpatial.Topology which is not as intuitive. Extent.ToEnvelope() and new Extent(myEnvelope) convert them. This is designed to be a virtual member to be overridden by subclasses, and should not be called directly by the constructor of inheriting classes.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.DataSet.Projection
member.summary: Gets or set the projection string

member.summary: Gets or sets the string type name that identifies this dataset

member.summary: Gets or sets the progress handler to use for internal actions taken by this dataset.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the RasterBoundData object, setting up a default RasterBounds.

member.summary: Occurs when the raster bounds of this data class have changed.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBoundDataSet.Reproject(DotSpatial.Projections.ProjectionInfo)
member.summary: RasterBounds datasets offer a limited sort of reproject on the fly. This tries to update the bounds by reprojecting the top left and bottom left and top right coordinates and updating the "affine" transform. This should not be used if CanReproject is false. Greater accuracy can be accomplished using the Projective transform, which is planned to be implemented as a toolbox function.
member.param: The projectionInfo to project to.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader
member.summary: The buffered binary reader was originally designed by Ted Dunsford to make shapefile reading more efficient, but ostensibly could be used for other binary reading exercises. To use this class, simply specify the BufferSize in bytes that you would like to use and begin reading values.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of BufferedBinaryReader.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader.Close
member.summary: Closes the internal binary reader and underlying file, but does not free the buffer that is in memory. For that, call the dispose method.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader.Dispose
member.summary: This will not close the file, so be sure to close before calling Dispose. This will dispose the file stream and set the buffer to null.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader.FillBuffer
member.summary: Instructs the reader to fill its buffer with data. This only does something if the buffer is not loaded yet. This method is optional since the first effort at reading the file will automatically load the buffer.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader.FillBuffer(System.Int32)
member.summary: This method will both assign a new maximum buffer size to the reader and force the reader to load the values into memory. This is unnecessary unless you plan on closing the file before reading values from this class. Even if values are loaded, this will assign the MaxBufferSize property so that future buffers have the specified size.
member.param: An integer buffer size to assign to the maximum buffer size before reading values.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BufferedBinaryReader.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Uses the seek method to quickly reach a desired location to begin reading. This will not buffer or read values. If the new position is beyond the end of the current buffer, the next read will load a new buffer.
member.param: A 64 bit integer specifying where to skip to in the file.
A System.IO.SeekOrigin enumeration specifying how to estimate the location.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.BoxStatistics
member.summary: Box-plot: Tukey 1977 Basically it is like subdividing the data into 4 quartiles, denoted like Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4. ------- Low Outlier (less than the Quartile - 3/2 Interquartile range) Q1 (Q1 - 3/2 the Interquartile range to Q1 Q2 (Quartile 1 to Median) Q3 (Median to Quartile 3) Q4 (Q3 to Q3 + 3/2 the Interquartile range High Outlier (Greater than Q3 plus the interquartile range

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.BoxStatistics.HighMedian
member.summary: The median between the median and the highest value. This separates the third and fourth quartiles.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.BoxStatistics.HighWisker
member.summary: The highest value that is not considered an outlier. If the values are not numeric, this will be the Maximum.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.BoxStatistics.LowMedian
member.summary: The median between the lowest value and the median value. This separates the first quartile from the second.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.BoxStatistics.LowWhisker
member.summary: The lowest value that is not considered to be an outlier. If the values are not numeric, this will be the minimum.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.BoxStatistics.Median
member.summary: The Median value (the value of the middle member)

member.param: The color to fill the image with

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BitmapGrid.ConvertToBitmap(System.Drawing.Image)
member.summary: Tests the specified bitmap to verify that it is both a Bitmap and in ARGB pixel format. If it is anything different, then this returns a newly created bitmap with a copy drawn onto it.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BitmapGrid.Difference(DotSpatial.Data.BitmapGrid)
member.summary: This will calculate the difference. The width and height of the new grid will be the larger of the rows and columns between the compare grid and this grid. Values outside the range of one of the grids will simply be filled in as the value stored in the other grid. Because byte values can't be negative, the difference will be the absolute value.
member.returns: A BitmapGrid with byte values calculated by taking the difference between the two grids.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BitmapGrid.Difference(DotSpatial.Data.BitmapGrid,System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default, all the bands have a difference comparison done. This may not have the desired effect because the alpha channel for most colors is actually just 255. The mathematical difference would be zero, resulting in an output image that, while being the actual difference, is essentially entirely invisibile (except where the images don't overlap.)

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.ImageCoverage
member.summary: TiledImage is a class for actually controlling the data in several tiles. This does not supply direct accessors for modifying the bytes directly, and instead expects the user to edit the image on a tile-by-tile basis. However, the GetBitmap method will produce a representation of the envelope scaled to the specified window.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.MwPng
member.summary: mw.png provides read-write support for a png format that also can provide overviews etc. This cannot work with any possible png file, but rather provides at least one common format that can be used natively for large files that is better at compression than just storing the values directly. http://www.w3.org/TR/2003/REC-PNG-20031110/#11PLTE

member.summary: Many rows may be evaluated by this process, but the first value in the array should be aligned with the left side of the image.
member.param: The original bytes to apply the PaethPredictor to.
The integer offset in the array where the filter should begin application. If this is 0, then it assumes that there is no previous scan-line to work with.
The number of bytes to filter, starting at the specified offset. This should be evenly divisible by the width.
The integer width of a scan-line for grabbing the c and b bytes
member.returns: The entire length of bytes starting with the specified offset

member.summary: Unfilters the data in order to reconstruct the original values.

the integer offset where reconstruction should begin
The integer length of bytes to deconstruct
The integer width of a scan-line in bytes (not counting any filter type bytes.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.PyramidImage
member.summary: The Pyramid Image is designed with the expectation that the image will be too big to access all at once. It is stored with multiple resolutions in a "mwi or DotSpatial Image" format. It is raw bytes in argb order. The header content is stored in xml format.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of PyramidImage

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.PyramidImage.#ctor(System.String)

member.summary: Creates a new Pyramid image, and uses the raster bounds to specify the number or rows and columns. No data is written at this time.

member.summary: For big images this won't work, but this gets the 0 scale original image as a bitmap.

member.summary: For big images the scale that is just one step larger than the specified window will be used.

member.param: The raster bounds for the original image.

the array of doubles in ABCDEF order X' = A + Bx + Cy Y' = D + Ex + Fy

member.summary: This assumes that the base image has been written to the file. This will now attempt to calculate the down-sampled images.

member.summary: downsamples this row by selecting every other byte

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.PyramidImage.Blur(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[])
member.summary: This is normally weighted for calculations for the middle row. If the top or bottom row is null, it will use mirror symetry by grabbing values from the other row instead.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.PyramidImage.ReadWindow(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This writes a window of byte values (ARGB order) to the file. This assumes that the headers already exist. If the headers have not been created or the bounds extend beyond the header numRows and numColumns for the specified scale, this will throw an exception.
member.param: The integer start row
The integer start column
The integer number of rows in the window
The integer number of columns in the window
The integer scale. 0 is the original image.
member.returns: The bytes created by this process
member.exception: Occurs when attempting to write data before the headers are defined
Occurs if the range specified is outside the bounds for the specified image scale

member.param: The byte array
The integer start row
The integer start column
The integer number of rows in the window
The integer number of columns in the window
The integer scale. 0 is the original image.
member.exception: Occurs when attempting to write data before the headers are defined
Occurs if the range specified is outside the bounds for the specified image scale

member.summary: This writes a window of byte values (ARGB order) to the file. This assumes that the headers already exist. If the headers have not been created or the bounds extend beyond the header numRows and numColumns for the specified scale, this will throw an exception.
member.param: The byte array
The integer start row
The integer start column
The integer number of rows in the window
The integer number of columns in the window
The integer scale. 0 is the original image.
The progress meter to advance by row. Calls Next() for each row.
member.exception: Occurs when attempting to write data before the headers are defined
Occurs if the range specified is outside the bounds for the specified image scale

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.PyramidImage.ReadBlock(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a block of data directly, converted into a bitmap. This is a general implementation, so assumes you are reading and writing to the 0 scale. This is always in ARGB format.
member.param: The zero based integer column offset from the left
The zero based integer row offset from the top
The integer number of pixel columns in the block.
The integer number of pixel rows in the block.
member.returns: A Bitmap that is xSize, ySize.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.PyramidImage.WriteBlock(System.Drawing.Bitmap,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves a bitmap of data as a continuous block into the specified location. This is a general implementation, so assumes you are reading and writing to the 0 scale. This should be in ARGB pixel format or it will fail.
member.param: The bitmap value to save.
The zero based integer column offset from the left
The zero based integer row offset from the top

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.HfaExt.ExtractTo(System.String,System.Int32@,System.String)
member.summary: A common task seems to be parsing the text up to a certain delimiter starting from a certain index, and then advancing the string pointer. This advances the index, extracting the string up to the point of the specified delimeter, or the end of the string, and advancing the string past the delimeter itself. If the index is equal to the length, then you are at the end of the string.

member.returns: An integer read from the string

member.summary: This variant of the ExtractTo algorithm effectively splits the string into teh content before the delimeter and after the delimeter, not counting the delimeter.
member.param: The string input
The string delimeter
the string remainder

The options to be used.

member.summary: This open method is only called if this plugin has been given priority for one of the file extensions supported in the DialogReadFilter property supplied by this control. member.param: A string specifying the complete path and extension of the file to open.
member.returns: An IDataSet to be added to the Map. These can also be groups of datasets.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBoundsExt.CellsContainingExtent(DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds,DotSpatial.Data.Extent)
member.summary: The affine transform can make figuring out what rows and columns are needed from the original image in order to correctly fill a geographic extent challenging. This attempts to handle that back projection problem. It returns a System.Drawing.Rectangle in pixel (cell) coordinates that is completely contains the geographic extents, but is not larger than the bounds of the underlying image. If geographic extent fully contains extent of IRasterBounds, than returns rectangle which contains full raster image. If geographic extent partially contains extent of IRasterBounds, than returns rectangle which contains needed edges of full raster image. It back projects all four corners of the extent and returns the bounding rectangle clipped by the image rectangle.
member.param: Instance of
Extent to test.
member.returns: Rectangle in pixel (cell) coordinates.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Raster.Xllcenter
member.summary: Gets or sets the X position of the lower left data cell. Setting this will adjust only the _affine[0] coefficient to ensure that the lower left corner ends up in the specified location, while keeping all the other affine coefficients the same. This is like a horizontal Translate that locks into place the center of the lower left corner of the image.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Raster.Yllcenter
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y position of the lower left data cell. Setting this will adjust only the _affine[0] coefficient to ensure that the lower left corner ends up in the specified location, while keeping all the other affine coefficients the same. This is like a horizontal Translate that locks into place the center of the lower left corner of the image.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.Raster`1.CopyWindow(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This creates a completely new raster from the windowed domain on the original raster. This new raster will not have a source file, and values like NumRowsInFile will correspond to the in memory version. All the values will be copied to the new source file. InRam must be true at this level.
member.param: The 0 based integer index of the top row to copy from this raster. If this raster is itself a window, 0 represents the startRow from the file.
The integer index of the bottom row to copy from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumRows - 1.
The 0 based integer index of the leftmost column to copy from this raster. If this raster is a window, 0 represents the startColumn from the file.
The 0 based integer index of the rightmost column to copy from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumColumns - 1
If this is true, the values are saved to the file. If this is false and the data can be loaded into Ram, no file handling is done. Otherwise, a file of NoData values is created.
Boolean. If this is true and the window is small enough, a copy of the values will be loaded into memory.
member.returns: An implementation of IRaster

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.Raster`1.GetStatistics
member.summary: Gets the statistics all the values. If the entire content is not currently in-ram, ReadRow will be used to read individual lines and performing the calculations.

member.summary: This creates an IN MEMORY ONLY window from the in-memory window of this raster. If, however, the requested range is outside of what is contained in the in-memory portions of this raster, an appropriate cast is required to ensure that you have the correct File handling, like a BinaryRaster etc.
member.param: The 0 based integer index of the top row to get from this raster. If this raster is itself a window, 0 represents the startRow from the file.
The integer index of the bottom row to get from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumRows - 1.
The 0 based integer index of the leftmost column to get from this raster. If this raster is a window, 0 represents the startColumn from the file.
The 0 based integer index of the rightmost column to get from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumColumns - 1
Boolean. If this is true and the window is small enough, a copy of the values will be loaded into memory.
member.returns: An implementation of IRaster

member.summary: If no file exists, this writes the header and no-data values. If a file exists, it will assume that data already has been filled in the file and will attempt to insert the data values as a window into the file. member.summary: Creates a completely empty raster that can be custom configured

member.summary: Creates a new BinaryRaster with the specified rows and columns. If if the raster is less than 64 Million cells, it will be created only in memory, and a Save method should be called when ready to save it to a file. Otherwise, it creates a blank file with NoData values...which start out as 0.
member.param: The fileName to write to
Integer number of rows
Integer number of columns

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BinaryRaster`1.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new BinaryRaster with the specified rows and columns. If inRam is true and the raster is less than 64 Million cells, it will be created only in memory, and a Save method should be called when ready to save it to a file. Otherwise, it creates a blank file with NoData values.
member.param: The fileName to write to
Integer number of rows
Integer number of columns
If this is true and the raster is small enough, it will load this into memory and not save anything to the file.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BinaryRaster`1.Copy(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a duplicate version of this file. If copyValues is set to false, then a raster of NoData values is created that has the same georeferencing information as the source file of this Raster, even if this raster is just a window. If the specified fileName exists, rather than throwing an exception or taking an "overwrite" parameter, this will throw the FileExists event, and cancel the copy if the cancel argument is set to true.
member.param: The string fileName specifying where to create the new file.
If this is false, the same size and georeferencing values are used, but they are all set to NoData.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BinaryRaster`1.CopyWindow(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This creates a completely new raster from the windowed domain on the original raster. This new raster will have a separate source file, and values like NumRowsInFile will correspond to the newly created file. All the values will be copied to the new source file. If inRam = true and the new raster is small enough, the raster values will be loaded into memory.
member.param: The 0 based integer index of the top row to copy from this raster. If this raster is itself a window, 0 represents the startRow from the file.
The integer index of the bottom row to copy from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumRows - 1.
The 0 based integer index of the leftmost column to copy from this raster. If this raster is a window, 0 represents the startColumn from the file.
The 0 based integer index of the rightmost column to copy from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumColumns - 1
If this is true, the values are saved to the file. If this is false and the data can be loaded into Ram, no file handling is done. Otherwise, a file of NoData values is created.
Boolean. If this is true and the window is small enough, a copy of the values will be loaded into memory.
member.returns: An implementation of IRaster

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BinaryRaster`1.GetStatistics
member.summary: Gets the statistics for the entire file, not just the window portion specified for this raster.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BinaryRaster`1.GetWindow(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This creates a window from this raster. The window will still save to the same source file, but only has access to a small window of data, so it can be loaded like a buffer. The georeferenced extents will be for the new window, not the original raster. startRow and endRow will exist in the new raster, however, so that it knows how to copy values back to the original raster.
member.param: The 0 based integer index of the top row to get from this raster. If this raster is itself a window, 0 represents the startRow from the file.
The integer index of the bottom row to get from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumRows - 1.
The 0 based integer index of the leftmost column to get from this raster. If this raster is a window, 0 represents the startColumn from the file.
The 0 based integer index of the rightmost column to get from this raster. The largest allowed value is NumColumns - 1
Boolean. If this is true and the window is small enough, a copy of the values will be loaded into memory.
member.returns: An implementation of IRaster

member.summary: Obtains only the statistics for the small window specified by startRow, endRow etc.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.BinaryRaster`1.Write(System.String)
member.summary: If no file exists, this writes the header and no-data values. If a file exists, it will assume that data already has been filled in the file and will attempt to insert the data values as a window into the file. If you want to create a copy of the file and values, just use System.IO.File.Copy, it almost certainly would be much more optimized.
member.param: The string fileName to write values to.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.AffineCoefficients
member.summary: Gets or sets the double affine coefficients that control the world-file positioning of this image. X' and Y' are real world coords. X' = [0] + [1] * Column + [2] * Row Y' = [3] + [4] * Column + [5] * Row

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.CellWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired width per cell. This will keep the skew the same, but will adjust both the column based and row based width coefficients in order to match the specified cell width. This can be thought of as the width of a bounding box that contains an entire grid cell, no matter if it is skewed.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.CellHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired height per cell. This will keep the skew the same, but will adjust both the column based and row based height coefficients in order to match the specified cell height. This can be thought of as the height of a bounding box that contains an entire grid cell, no matter if it is skewed.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.Extent
member.summary: Gets or sets the rectangular confines for this envelope. The skew will remain the same when setting this, but the image will be translated and stretched to fit in the specified envelope.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.NumRows
member.summary: Gets the number of rows in the raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.NumColumns
member.summary: Gets the number of columns in the raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IRasterBounds.WorldFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the world file name. This won't do anything until the "Load" or "Save" methods are called.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.CellWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired width per cell. This will keep the skew the same, but will adjust both the column based and row based width coefficients in order to match the specified cell width. This can be thought of as the width of a bounding box that contains an entire grid cell, no matter if it is skewed.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.CellHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired height per cell. This will keep the skew the same, but will adjust both the column based and row based height coefficients in order to match the specified cell height. This can be thought of as the height of a bounding box that contains an entire grid cell, no matter if it is skewed.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.Extent
member.summary: Gets or sets the rectangular bounding box for this raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets the height of the entire bounds. This is derived by considering both the column and row based contributions to the overall height. Changing this will keep the skew ratio the same, but adjust both portions so that the overall height will match the specified height.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.NumRows
member.summary: Gets the number of rows in the raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.NumColumns
member.summary: Gets the number of columns in the raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the geographic width of this raster. This will include the skew term in the width estimate, so it will adjust both the width and the skew coefficient, but preserve the ratio of skew to cell width.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.WorldFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the fileName of the wordfile that describes the geographic coordinates of this raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.X
member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal placement of the upper left corner of this bounds. Because of the skew, this upper left position may not actually be the same as the upper left corner of the image itself (_affine[0]). Instead, this is the top left corner of the rectangular extent for this raster.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.RasterBounds.Y
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical placement of the upper left corner of this bounds, which is the same as the top. The top left corner of the actual image may not be in this position because of skew, but this represents the maximum Y value of the rectangular extents that contains the image.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.Feature
member.summary: A generic vector feature that has the geometry and data components but no drawing information

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature
member.summary: A feature doesn't need to be abstract because the geometry is generic and the other properties are all the same. It supports IRenderable so that even if you don't know what type of feature this is, you can still tell it to draw itself. You won't be able to specify any drawing characteristics from this object however.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.Copy
member.summary: Creates a deep copy of this feature. the new datarow created will not be connected to a data Table, so it should be added to one.
member.returns: Returns a deep copy of this feature as an IFeature

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.ToShape
member.summary: Creates a new shape based on this feature by itself.
member.returns: A Shape object

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.CopyAttributes(DotSpatial.Data.IFeature)
member.summary: This uses the field names to copy attribute values from the source to this feature. Even if columns are missing or if there are extra columns, this method should work.
member.param: The IFeature source to copy attributes from.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.DataRow
member.summary: Gets the datarow containing all the attributes related to this geometry

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.BasicGeometry
member.summary: Gets or sets a valid IBasicGeometry associated with the data elements of this feature. This will be enough geometry information to cast into a full fledged geometry that can be used in coordination with DotSpatial.Analysis

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.ContentLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the content length. If the geometry for this shape was loaded from a file, this contains the size of this shape in 16-bit words as per the Esri Shapefile specification.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.EnvelopeSource
member.summary: Gets or sets a DotSpatial.Data.CacheTypes enumeration specifying whether the Envelope property returns a cached value in this object or is retrieved directly from the geometry. The initial case for Shapefiles is to use a cache. Setting the envelope assumes that you are going to use a cached value and will set this to Cached. Setting this to Dynamic will cause the Envelope property to reference the geometry.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.Fid
member.summary: Gets the key that is associated with this feature. This returns -1 if this feature is not a member of a feature layer.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.ParentFeatureSet
member.summary: Gets a reference to the IFeatureLayer that contains this item.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.RecordNumber
member.summary: An index value that is saved in some file formats.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.ShapeType
member.summary: When a shape is loaded from a Shapefile, this will identify whether M or Z values are used and whether or not the shape is null.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.IFeature.ShapeIndex
member.summary: This is simply a quick access to the Vertices list for this specific feature. If the Vertices have not yet been defined, this will be null.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.ComparisonField
member.summary: Gets or sets the column to use when sorting lists of features. If this is set to a column not in the field, the FID is used instead. This should be assigned before attempting to sort features. Because this is static, it only has to be set once, and will affect all the individual comparisions until it is set differently.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.System#IComparable{DotSpatial#Data#IFeature}#CompareTo(DotSpatial.Data.IFeature)
member.summary: The FID comparison will be very slow, so this should only be used if the ComparisonField property is set. This will allow sorting features based on their data-row attributes. The data rows do not have to be identical, as long as both contain a column with the comparison field.
member.param: The other IFeature to compare to.
member.returns: An integer that controls the sorting based on the values for the specified field name.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.NumParts
member.summary: Gets or sets the integer number of parts associated with this feature. Setting this will set a cached value on the feature that is separate from the geometry and set the NumParts to Cached.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.NumPartsSource
member.summary: Gets or sets a DotSpatial.Data.CacheTypes enumeration. If the value is dynamic, then NumParts will be read from the geometry on this feature. If it is cached, then the value is separate from the geometry.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.Offset
member.summary: This specifies the offset, if any in the data file

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.BasicGeometry
member.summary: Gets or sets a valid IBasicGeometry associated with the data elements of this feature. This will be enough geometry information to cast into a full fledged geometry that can be used in coordination with DotSpatial.Analysis

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.ContentLength
member.summary: If the geometry for this shape was loaded from a file, this contains the size of this shape in 16-bit words as per the Esri Shapefile specification.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.Coordinates
member.summary: Returns an array of coordinates corresponding to the basic feature.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.DataRow
member.summary: Gets the datarow containing all the attributes related to this geometry. This will query the parent feature layer's data Table by FID and then cache the value locally. If no parent feature layer exists, then this is meaningless. You should create a new Feature by doing FeatureLayer.Features.Add(), which will return a new Feature.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.Envelope
member.summary: This is an envelope, but specified by the file, not by calculating from the geometry. To obtain a calculated envelope, calling the DynamicEnvelope()

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.EnvelopeSource
member.summary: Gets or sets a DotSpatial.Data.CacheTypes enumeration specifying whether the Envelope property returns a cached value in this object or is retrieved directly from the geometry. The initial case for Shapefiles is to use a cache. Setting the envelope assumes that you are going to use a cached value and will set this to Cached. Setting this to Dynamic will cause the Envelope property to reference the geometry.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.FeatureType
member.summary: Returns either Point, Polygon or Line

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.Fid
member.summary: Gets the key that is associated with this feature. This returns -1 if this feature is not a member of a feature layer.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.GeometryType
member.summary: Shows the type of geometry for this feature

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.NumGeometries
member.summary: Returns the NumGeometries in the BasicGeometry of this feature

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.NumPoints
member.summary: Gets the integer number of points associated with features.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.RecordNumber

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.ParentFeatureSet

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.ShapeType

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Feature.ShapeIndex
member.summary: This is simply a quick access to the Vertices list for this specific feature. If the Vertices have not yet been defined, this will be null.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.FeatureSet
member.summary: Rather than being an abstract base class, this is a "router" class that will make decisions based on the file extension or whatever being used and decide the best IFeatureSet that matches the specifications.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.IFeatureSet
member.summary: A layer contains a list of features of a specific type that matches the geometry type. While this supports IRenderable, this merely forwards the drawing instructions to each of its members, but does not allow the control of any default layer properties here. Calling FeatureDataSource.Open will create a number of layers of the appropriate specific type and also create a specific layer type that is derived from this class that does expose default "layer" properties, as well as the symbology elements.

member.summary: For attributes that are small enough to be loaded into a data table, this will join attributes from a foreign table (from an excel file). The field name to join on in this table
The field in the foreign table.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeatureSet.AddShape(DotSpatial.Data.Shape)
member.summary: If this featureset is in index mode, this will append the vertices and shapeindex of the shape. Otherwise, this will add a new feature based on this shape. If the attributes of the shape are not null, this will attempt to append a new datarow It is up to the developer to ensure that the object array of attributes matches the this featureset. If the Attributes of this feature are loaded, this will add the attributes in ram only. Otherwise, this will attempt to insert the attributes as a new record using the "AddRow" method. The schema of the object array should match this featureset's column schema.
member.param: The shape to add to this featureset.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeatureSet.AddShapes(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DotSpatial.Data.Shape})
member.summary: Adds any type of list or array of shapes. If this featureset is not in index moded, it will add the features to the featurelist and suspend events for faster copying.
member.param: An enumerable collection of shapes.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeatureSet.GetFeature(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the specified feature by constructing it from the vertices, rather than requiring that all the features be created. (which takes up a lot of memory).
member.param: The integer index

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.IFeatureSet.GetShape(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets a shape at the specified shape index. If the featureset is in indexmode, this returns a copy of the shape. If not, it will create a new shape based on the specified feature.
member.param: The zero based integer index of the shape.

If getAttributes is true, then this also try to get attributes for that shape. If attributes are loaded, then it will use the existing datarow. Otherwise, it will read the attributes from the file. (This second option is not recommended for large repeats. In such a case, the attributes can be set manually from a larger bulk query of the data source.)
member.returns: The Shape object

member.param: The DataRow for which to obtaind the feature
member.returns: The feature to obtain that is associated with the specified data row.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.FieldJoinType.All
member.summary: Output datasets have all fields from both input and output sets. Fields with duplicate field names will be appended with a number. Features from this dataset may appear more than once if more than one valid intersection occurs with the features from the other featureset.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.FieldJoinType.ForeignOnly
member.summary: The fields will be created from the fields in the other featureset.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.FieldJoinType.LocalOnly
member.summary: All the fields from this FeatureSet are used, and all of the features from the other featureset are considered to be a single geometry so that features from this set will appear no more than once in the output set.

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.FieldJoinType.None
member.summary: No fields will be copied, but features from this featureset will be considered independantly and added as separate features to the output featureset.

member.summary: This doesn't rewrite the entire header or erase the existing content. This simply replaces the file length in the file with the new file length. This is generally because we want to write the header first, but don't know the total length of a new file until cycling through the entire file. It is easier, therefore to update the length after editing.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.Shapefile.BufferSize
member.summary: The buffer size is an integer value in bytes specifying how large a piece of memory can be used at any one time. Reading and writing from the disk is faster when done all at once. The larger this number the more effective the disk management, but the more ram will be required (and the more likely to trip an out of memory error).

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.WkbFeatureReader.ReadShape(System.IO.Stream,DotSpatial.Topology.FeatureType)
member.summary: Attempts to read in an entry to the specified feature type. If the feature type does not match the geometry type, this will return null. (A Point geometry will be accepted by MultiPoint feature type, but not the other way arround. Either way, this will advance the reader through the shape feature. Using the Unspecified will always return the shape it reads, or null in the case of mixed feature collections which are not supported.

member.summary: Gets an enumerator. This exists to make it easier to cycle values, but in truth should not be used because it re-adds the property accessor which slows down the data access, which is the whole point of putting all the vertices into a jagged array of doubles in the first place.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.VertexRange.PartOffset
member.summary: For parts, controlling the part offset is perhaps more useful that controlling the shape offset.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.VertexRange.ShapeOffset
member.summary: The StartIndex is the sum of the shape offset and the part offset. Controlling them separately allows the entire shape offset to be adjusted independantly after the part is created.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.VertexRange.StartIndex
member.summary: The integer index of the first vertex included in this range. This is overridden in the case of part ranges to also take into account the shape start index.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.VertexRange.EndIndex
member.summary: the integer index of the last vertex included in this range

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Data.VertexRange.NumVertices

member.summary: Gets or sets the vertices

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.VertexRange.VertexRangeEnumerator
member.summary: The enumerator is here to provide an easy method for cycling vertex values in each range. This sort of defeats the point because it adds two method calls for advancing each step (one to MoveNext and one to access the property. The whole point of loading everything into a single array of vertices in the first place is to avoid property accessors slowing down the process. However, it's here if someone wants it.

Failing to provide a DialogReadFilter will result in this plugin being added to the list of DataProviders being supplied under the Add Other Data option in the file menu.

member.summary: 11 - Each shape is a point with a Z value

member.summary: 13 - Each shape is a linestring with each vertex having a z value

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.ShapeType.PolygonZ
member.summary: 15 - Each shape is a closed linestring with each vertex having a z value

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.ShapeType.MultiPointZ
member.summary: 18 - Each shape has several unconnected points, each of which has a z value

member.name: F:DotSpatial.Data.ShapeType.PointM

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.EventList`1.AfterRangeRemoved
member.summary: Occurs after an item is removed from the List. Gives a handle to the range that was removed, but it no longer has a meaningful index value or an option to cancel.

member.summary: Occurs before an item is added to the List. There is no index yet specified because it will be added to the end of the list.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeRangeAdded
member.summary: Occurs before a range of items is added to the list. There is no index yet, but this event can be cancelled.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterItemAdded
member.summary: Occurs after an item has already been added to the list. The index where the item was added is specified.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterRangeAdded
member.summary: Occurs after a range has already been added to the list. This reveals the index where the beginning of the range was added, but cannot be canceled.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeClearing
member.summary: Occurs before a clear action, allowing the event to be canceled.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterClearing
member.summary: Occurs after a clear action, allowing the event to be cancled

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.ListChanged
member.summary: Occurs after a method that changes either the order or the members of this EventDictionary

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeItemInserted
member.summary: Occurs before an item is inserted. The index of the requested insertion as well as the item being inserted and an option to cancel the event are specified

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeRangeInserted
member.summary: Occurs before a range is inserted. The index of the requested insertion location as well as the item being inserted and an option to cancel the event are provided in the event arguments

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterItemInserted
member.summary: Occurs after an item is inserted. Shows the true index of the item after it was actually added.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterRangeInserted
member.summary: Occurs after an item is inserted. Shows the true index of the item after it was actually added.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeItemRemoved
member.summary: Occurs before an item is removed from the List. Specifies the item, the current index and an option to cancel.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeRangeRemoved
member.summary: Occurs before a range is removed from the List. Specifies the range, the current index and an option to cancel.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterItemRemoved
member.summary: Occurs after an item is removed from the List. Gives a handle to the item that was removed, but it no longer has a meaningful index value or an option to cancel.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterRangeRemoved
member.summary: Occurs after an item is removed from the List. Gives a handle to the range that was removed, but it no longer has a meaningful index value or an option to cancel.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeAllMatchingRemoved
member.summary: Occurs before all the elements that match a predicate are removed. Supplies an IEnumerable list in the event args of all the items that will match the expression. This action can be cancelled.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterAllMatchingRemoved
member.summary: Occurs after all the elements that matched a predicate were removed. The values are the items that were successfully removed. The action has already happened, and so cannot be cancelled here.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.BeforeItemSet
member.summary: Occurs before an item is set. This event can cancel the set opperation.

member.name: E:DotSpatial.Data.IEventDictionary`2.AfterItemSet
member.summary: Occurs after an item is successfully set

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Data.SubclassList`2
member.summary: SubclassList is brilliant if I do say so myself. Let's say you have a list of IPointCategory, which is a subclass of IFeatureCategory. You can't have a strong typed List that is both without creating a special class that can deal with the specific implementations of each. So I was writing all of the stupid type specific collection classes, when in reality, I just needed a class like this that could handle the business logic. Then specific instances can just inherit from this class, but specify the two types.
member.typeparam: The base type that is inherited
The sub type that inherits from the base type

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Data.SubclassList`2.Add(`1)
member.summary: Allows adding of the sub type
